content.raw:
Did you commit the `code_checker` fixes? I still see the errors.

Just as a tip, don't approve your own pull request. When we look down the list of pull-requests to review, if we see 2 approvals for a pull-request then we are more likely to skip over it.
content.html:
Did you commit the code_checker fixes? I still see the errors.

Just as a tip, don't approve your own pull request. When we look down the list of pull-requests to review, if we see 2 approvals for a pull-request then we are more likely to skip over it.

content.raw:
Thanks for making the changes, they look good. Before this is ready to be merged, there are just some very minor coding style changes that we try to enforce. 

Running the command below from gazebo build dir should show help pick up a few (it takes some time):


```
#!c++

sh code/code_checker.sh
```



I will leave inline comments for the ones that I found.
content.html:
Thanks for making the changes, they look good. Before this is ready to be merged, there are just some very minor coding style changes that we try to enforce.

Running the command below from gazebo build dir should show help pick up a few (it takes some time):

sh code/code_checker.sh

I will leave inline comments for the ones that I found.

pullrequest.title: Add animate_box example and update animate_pose example to support current version.

content.html:
You can do pose addition, but be careful since it's non-commutative (order matters).

math::Pose linkPoseRelativeToModel;
math::Pose modelPoseRelativeToWorld;
math::Pose LinkPoseRelativeToWorld =
  linkPoseRelativeToModel + modelPoseRelativeToWorld;

See the documentation in Pose.hh

content.raw: I just did a quick test, inserting a double_pendulum_with_base into a world and looking at the `~/pose/info` and `~/pose/local/info`. It has the pose for 4 entities: the model `double_pendulum_with_base` and its three links `double_pendulum_with_base::base`, `double_pendulum_with_base::upper_link`, and `double_pendulum_with_base::lower_link`. It looks like each model pose is relative to the world, while the link poses are relative to the model pose.
content.html: I just did a quick test, inserting a double_pendulum_with_base into a world and looking at the ~/pose/info and ~/pose/local/info. It has the pose for 4 entities: the model double_pendulum_with_base and its three links double_pendulum_with_base::base, double_pendulum_with_base::upper_link, and double_pendulum_with_base::lower_link. It looks like each model pose is relative to the world, while the link poses are relative to the model pose.

pull_request.title: Add animate_box example and update animate_pose example to support current version.

pullrequest.title: Add animate_box example and update animate_pose example to support current version.

content.raw:
I may have been recalling incorrectly. I viewed the data for a model with several joints and moved the model around without moving the joints relative to the model. It looked like the joint poses were relatively fixed small numbers in ~/pose/local/info, while the model pose varied significantly as the model moved. When I used ~/pose/info, the joints appeared to vary their location values more significantly.

Essentially my question is this:
What coordinate frame are each point type broadcast in for each topic?
content.html:
I may have been recalling incorrectly. I viewed the data for a model with several joints and moved the model around without moving the joints relative to the model. It looked like the joint poses were relatively fixed small numbers in ~/pose/local/info, while the model pose varied significantly as the model moved. When I used ~/pose/info, the joints appeared to vary their location values more significantly.

Essentially my question is this: What coordinate frame are each point type broadcast in for each topic?

pull_request.title: Add animate_box example and update animate_pose example to support current version.

pullrequest.title: Add animate_box example and update animate_pose example to support current version.

content.raw:
Actually, `~/pose/local/info` and `~/pose/info`
[use the same coordinate frame](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d6bfa5238c7c0cb3963716df16475b97f1f0051b/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=default#cl-1877).
I think the main difference is that `~/pose/local/info` can have higher bandwidth and is intended to be used just within the server, eventually intended to be replaced by shared memory (according to [this comment in World.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d6bfa5238c7c0cb3963716df16475b97f1f0051b/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=default#cl-185)).
content.html: Actually, ~/pose/local/info and ~/pose/info use the same coordinate frame. I think the main difference is that ~/pose/local/info can have higher bandwidth and is intended to be used just within the server, eventually intended to be replaced by shared memory (according to this comment in World.cc).

content.raw: There are very good reasons to use local pose, particularly if operating in a large coordinate system where floating point precision starts to matter.

content.raw:
Reviewing the thingy once more, what about adding the new animate_joint plugin and animate_pose to our building tests mechanism?

```
diff -r de20d7921de6 test/examples/example_plugins.cc
--- a/test/examples/example_plugins.cc	Fri Mar 21 17:47:09 2014 -0700
+++ b/test/examples/example_plugins.cc	Wed Mar 26 23:11:00 2014 +0100
@@ -83,6 +83,8 @@
   , "world_edit"
   , "model_push"
   , "factory"
+  , "animate_joints"
+  , "animate_pose"
 ));
```
content.html:
Reviewing the thingy once more, what about adding the new animate_joint plugin and animate_pose to our building tests mechanism?

diff -r de20d7921de6 test/examples/example_plugins.cc
--- a/test/examples/example_plugins.cc  Fri Mar 21 17:47:09 2014 -0700
+++ b/test/examples/example_plugins.cc  Wed Mar 26 23:11:00 2014 +0100
@@ -83,6 +83,8 @@
   , "world_edit"
   , "model_push"
   , "factory"
+  , "animate_joints"
+  , "animate_pose"
 ));

content.raw: not sure if we want to promote the use of `~/pose/local/info` here. It was mainly an internal thing to get timestamped poses working properly on the server side. I think `~/pose/info` is a better choice.
content.html: not sure if we want to promote the use of ~/pose/local/info here. It was mainly an internal thing to get timestamped poses working properly on the server side. I think ~/pose/info is a better choice.

Actually, you are right. I was mixing the testing done on test/examples with the examples/ directory.

@scpeters I would say that the spirit of get the examples build that you started should also include this code that is completely untested right now.

content.raw: The standard gazebo team policy is to get two approvals before merging the pull request. Sorry but this comes in the middle of the works for preparing the gazebo 3.0 release so it could take a bit more than usual. Please be patient :)
